## 1. Dataset

**DC Metro Crime Data**  
**Kaggle**  

**Short Description:**  

This is a DC Metro Crime Dataset that contains records of crimes in the Washington DC Metropolitan area from December 31st, 2007, to November 2nd, 2017. This dataset provides an extremely rich source for analyzing crime patterns and determining key trends. This dataset is relevant to our purpose of identifying burglary patterns, as it includes a variety of variables like offense, shift, block, district, etc. For our project, we will use the two key variables, offense and shift, to determine the time of day burglaries have occurred.

## 3. Research Question


> _Does the frequency of burglary incidents in the DC Metro area differ across different times of the day?_


---

## 4. Modeling Approach / Models Used

Describe what you plan to do analytically.

- Type of task (check all that apply):
  - [ ] Exploratory analysis only  
  - [ ] Regression (predicting a numeric value)  
  - [ ] Classification (predicting categories/labels)  
  - [ ] Clustering / unsupervised patterns  
  - [X] Other (describe)
  
We plan to analyze two categorical variables to see if there is a difference in the amount of burglaries (OFFENSE) depending on the time of day (SHIFT).

**Planned models / methods:**

Method: The method we decided to use after discussing with each other, is hypothesis testing. We will be specifically targeting burglary as the type of offense and the shifts (time of day) will be the other variable we will be measuring. 

Null Hypothesis: There is no difference in the occurrence of burglary during any time of day (meaning there is no specific time of day where burglary is more common. 

Alternative hypothesis: There is a difference in the occurrence of burglary during a time of day (meaning a specific time of day has more burglaries occurring than the other times of day. In this case, we believe that during the night, there will be the most amount of burglaries being committed.) 


**Planned evaluation metrics:**

- Count of burglaries
- Percentage of burglary during different shifts

---

## 5. Expected Results

We believe that we will see the most amount of burglary being committed in the DC metro area at night time. Our reasoning here is just common sense, it makes sense for burglaries to occur at night where most people are asleep or away and with visibility being very low during the night, this allows criminals to get away with much more compared to the daytime.
